newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Dec 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Dec 17.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The African National Congress is in a race against time to overturn a court interdict halting the nomination of Ivy Matsepe-Cassaburi as Free State Premier, or face a constitutional crisis that could see the province without a premier and executive committee into the new year.

- Sun International South Africa Ltd chairman Buddy Hawton has quietly stepped down from his position, only a year after assuming the role following the much publicised departure of former Sun boss Sol Kerzner as chairman of the casino group.

- Hertz Rent-a-Car is reinvesting in South Africa after leaving the country nearly 10 years ago and is promising stiff competition in the car rental market, particularly to Imperial and Avis, the biggest in the industry.
- Government is in talks with the Chamber of Mines and National Union of Mineworkers on a proposal to use institutional housing subsidies to overhaul the mine hostel system.

- Boeing and McDonnel Douglas, two of the world's three largest passenger aircraft manufacturers, announced a $13.3 billion share-swap merger at the weekend to form a $48 billion-a-year aerospace defence company.
- The South African Futures Exchange plans to launch a wheat futures contract next year as deregulation and the demise of agricultural marketing boards gather pace.

- Macadams Bakery Supplies Holdings, South Africa's largest supplier of bakery equipment, has signed a joint venture agreement with three international companies in a move to double the company's exports withing the next two years.
- The Cullinan Hotel and Leisure group will appear on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange boards on January 6 after a reverse listing through Concorde Travel Holdings Ltd.
- The South African Tourism Organisation is having to create alternative sources of income to sustain its initiatives to lure British tourists to South Africa.
- Police and People Against Gangsterism and Drugs supporters rampaged past terrified tourists and holiday-makers outside Cape Town International Airport on Monday.
- President Nelson Mandela discussed the conflicts in Zaire and Burundi with eight other African leaders for two hours before leaving the summit early for home.
- Sir Laurens van der Post, the South African-born writer and mentor of Britain's Prince Charles, has died peacefully at his London home. He was 90.
